channel.title: Why is Project Insanity considered "bad"?
channel.description: Why do most RSPS coders, intermediate - advanced, say that Project Insanity (PI) is a shitty base? I'm not saying it's good, I'm just wondering why.

item.title: Why is Project Insanity considered "bad"?
item.dc:creator: @Vix Vix
item.description:
@Vix wrote:

Its the definition of spaghetti code, try to create a flow-chart for it…

Read full topic

item.title: Why is Project Insanity considered "bad"?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“Shaloxis, post:12, topic:542304”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=661181.msg4419794#msg4419794 date=1397860127]
it is written badly.
[/quote]Not true.

It is not written badly,
However the packages are very messy, but this is easy to solve.
You see more and more releases that have completely re-packaged their whole server.
For example Krithium, Project Exile, etc.

It takes some time, but using eclipse, you can easily pick out every single non-used code.
Which could also fix ALOT of mem leaks.[/quote]
Say that again when you can’t support more then 20 players or when 90% of your game content contains a dupe. What about that heavy benchmark? There is also instability + you can’t say it’s good code when you know there’s a memory leak. You can’t expect developers to fix bad code for you.

Read full topic

item.title: Why is Project Insanity considered "bad"?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

I don’t even know what to say in this thread.

Read full topic

item.title: Why is Project Insanity considered "bad"?
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“Shaloxis, post:12, topic:542304”]Not true.

It is not written badly[/quote]
yes it is

Shaloxis:

However the packages are very messy, but this is easy to solve.

the packaging literally has nothing to do with the performance of a server at all, the original runesource doesn’t even have any packages and it still outperforms project insanity

[quote=“Shaloxis, post:12, topic:542304”]You see more and more releases that have completely re-packaged their whole server.
For example Krithium, Project Exile, etc.[/quote]
again… all shit servers, the packaging has nothing to do with the performance

Shaloxis:

It takes some time, but using eclipse, you can easily pick out every single non-used code.

there’s a lot more to project insanity that’s bad than just dead code.

  • does not scale well at all
  • main loop is jammed with tons of code which causes lag
  • no object orientation
  • no packet validation (which is why it has so many dupes)
  • misuse of concurrent locks
  • some use task systems that run on their own dedicated thread which isn’t thread safe

and so much more that by time you’re done fixing it, it’ll look like a half assed worse performing version of Runesource… so why not just use Runesource (or any other base for that matter) to begin with? doesn’t it seem illogical to waste time cleaning out a project insanity when you can DL another server and start working straight away?

Shaloxis:

Which could also fix ALOT of mem leaks.

memory leaks are caused by keeping references to unused Objects, removing dead code isn’t necessarily going to stop memory leaks

Read full topic

item.title: Why is Project Insanity considered "bad"?
item.dc:creator: @sorecheeny sorecheeny
item.description:
@sorecheeny wrote:

The way the base is set up is very disgusting in my opinion. There’s also a lot of exploits that come with it, that can be very tricky, especially to beginners. I see servers that are PI all the time that have constant dupes, and glitches, so that’s why I pick Runesource.

Read full topic

item.title: Why is Project Insanity considered "bad"?
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

Although it is generally easy to use and work with, it goes against a lot of object oriented related ideals. I guess this is a good example to incorporate the saying “just because it works doesn’t mean it’s right”. Personally, I loved working with Project Insanity when I was into private server emulation, but every since I’ve started practicing good programming habits, I’ve realized how many mistakes I’ve made in past times.

Read full topic

item.title: Why is Project Insanity considered "bad"?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Shaloxis, post:12, topic:542304”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=661181.msg4419794#msg4419794 date=1397860127]
it is written badly.
[/quote]Not true.

It is not written badly,
However the packages are very messy, but this is easy to solve.
You see more and more releases that have completely re-packaged their whole server.
For example Krithium, Project Exile, etc.

It takes some time, but using eclipse, you can easily pick out every single non-used code.
Which could also fix ALOT of mem leaks.[/quote]
I use PI, and I use it a lot.
The base is indeed written badly, there is a lot of dead code (Talking about the original), and you don’t even want to get me started on how many times Insanity called static methods in a non-static way. Sure, some things are easy to fix (esp. for the above-average users), but then you have things like the combat system (oh god the horrors), playersaving (not so much), all the extra code in client.java’s process method, etc. I could go on, really.

But that’s not all what is wrong with it. What’s wrong with it is that it was one of the more known “named” server/client packages. It was better to use then delta because of packaging and some other crap. It took the net by storm, and there were like 300 new servers up/day because of how easy it was to plug and play (What i mean is, is download it, change a name, and host). With this huge ass wave of servers coming up, there was one fatal flaw. 90% of the owners didn’t know 2-shits about java (tbh I was one of em at one point) so they threw in code they copy/pasted either from other parts of the server, the internet, or from some friend.

All they did was pile bad code onto more bad code, creating a pile of crap. Then eventually those kids finally decided to learn how to code, and started making better progress at cleaning up PI and making it better. But eventually they realize:

Vain_:

by the time you get the server to it’s backbones - which is what needs to be improved first - you could have already written something much more efficient, and you can call it your own!

That’s when you started seeing Hyperion, Rune Source, etc popping up.

Now, yet again, we’re at the stage where a bunch of servers are being released without much being done to them (this time it’s with 7XX because of matrix). Difference is the base code was overall written better than PI.

tl;dr: PI is not just shit because of the base code, it’s shit because of shit kids adding shit into it making it more shitty.

Read full topic

item.title: Why is Project Insanity considered "bad"?
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

[quote=“Shaloxis, post:12, topic:542304”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=661181.msg4419794#msg4419794 date=1397860127]
it is written badly.
[/quote]Not true.

It is not written badly,
However the packages are very messy, but this is easy to solve.
You see more and more releases that have completely re-packaged their whole server.
For example Krithium, Project Exile, etc.

It takes some time, but using eclipse, you can easily pick out every single non-used code.
Which could also fix ALOT of mem leaks.[/quote]it is written badly. and packages have nothing to do with it. “unused code” is not the same as “bad code” and you can’t fix a memory leak by removing unused method calls.

item.title: Why is Project Insanity considered "bad"?
item.dc:creator: @Shaloxis Shaloxis
item.description:
@Shaloxis wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:4, topic:542304”]it is written badly.[/quote]Not true.

It is not written badly,
However the packages are very messy, but this is easy to solve.
You see more and more releases that have completely re-packaged their whole server.
For example Krithium, Project Exile, etc.

It takes some time, but using eclipse, you can easily pick out every single non-used code.
Which could also fix ALOT of mem leaks.

item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

should probably focus on learning the language first. you won’t be able to tell what’s wrong or what’s used poorly if you don’t know the fundamentals of the API and how the content should function.

@Vain1 wrote:

then how exactly would you know how to “remove all the bad stuff” and “improve” anything?

if you have no knowledge or capability of improving a server’s stability or security - you should simply use one that is more viable to your needs.

it is written badly.

It works though.

The best thing to do before using a PI server, is actually throw all the shit out and start improving the foundation of the server
[/quote]“it works though” is a horrible thing to say in the field of programming.

by the time you get the server to it’s backbones - which is what needs to be improved first - you could have already written something much more efficient, and you can call it your own![/quote]
